title: Walks Around Finchale Abbey Walking Route

images.title: Mat Fascione / Finchale Priory and the River Wear
images.caption: Finchale Priory and the River Wear. The priory was an outpost of Durham Cathedral and was utilised as a holiday retreat for the monks of Durham until its suppression in 1538.

images.title: Trevor Littlewood / Bridge at Finchale Priory
images.caption: Bridge to the woodland on the other side of the abbey.

images.title: Banks of the River Wear at Finchale Priory by Robert Graham, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

images.title: Steve McShane / Finchale Priory from across the river...
images.caption: Finchale Priory from across the river with footbridge also shown.

description: This walk visits the ancient Finchale Abbey in Framwellgate Moor, County Durham. The English Heritage owned site dates back to the 13th-century and is designated as a Grade I listed building. Today you can enjoy a pleasant stroll along the River Wear and around the extensive remaining ruins. After exploring the ruins you can cross the footbridge and enjoy a walk around the riverside woodland on the eastern bank. The Weardale Way passes right by the abbey. You could pick up the waymarked trail and follow it south into the city of Durham to extend the walk. Here you could visit the famous cathedral and pick up the Durham Riverside Walk along the River Wear.
